localizedDescriptions.en: Generic encounter or progress note composition.
Details of composition-level context specific to a GP Contact event.
The original record identifier of the encounter/composition level record in the source GP system.
A generic heading used by openHR records.
Suggested design pattern for including an Adverse Reaction List in a template.
Details of a harmful or undesirable effect, including allergy and intolerance, associated with known or suspected exposure to a drug or other medicinal substance.
Details of the agent or medicinal substance believed to be the cause of the adverse reaction or allergy.

annotations.comment:
For GP2GP V2 use, it is currently anticipated that there will be 4 permissible ways to express a Causative agent: 
Drug Group (SNOMED-CT),
dm+d VMP/AMP (dm+d), 
Ingredient (SNOMED-CT),
 TradeFamily/TradeFamilyGroup (SNOMED-CT).
 It is MANDATORY that one and only one of these must always be selected. Optionally, in addition a SNOMED AllergyCode may be sent as a mapping, but can never be sent on its own. 
For legacy use other codes are permissible such as FDB Agent codes, EMIS Drug codes and READ codes but these should be carried as simple free text and the coded information carried in mappings/translation attributes. This kind of coding is not regarded as being safe to trigger decision support outwith the native GP system.
The exact subset definitions have not yet been agreed and may change prior to full implementation.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details of a single reaction thought to be due to the causative agent.
The date that the reaction was clinically recorded/asserted. This will  often equate to the date of onset of the reaction but this may not be wholly clear from source data.

annotations.comment: From Welsh IHR / openHR model.

localizedDescriptions.en: Any additional comment or clarification about the adverse reaction.

annotations.comment: From Welsh IHR model

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of a treatment, medicine, vaccine or procedure which should not be administered or performed on this subject.
Identified contraindication to a treatment, medicine, vaccine or procedure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the identified Contraindication with a terminology is desirable, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Evidence or rationale for the contraindication.

annotations.comment: This should be explicitly stated, so that this rationale can be explicit if this data is shared in a message or with another clinical system, although an optional link to evidence within the same record is also permitted.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the contraindication was most recently deemed to apply, normally as a result of  clinical assertion or affirmation.
Positive statement/s about adverse reactions that need to be recorded as clinically excluded from the health record at a specific point in time.
A statement about exclusion of known adverse reactions in the health record.

annotations.comment: For example: "No known adverse reactions"; "No known adverse reaction to" (penicillin).

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the Exclusion not captured in other fields.
The date at which the exclusion was last clinically asserted, affirmed or confirmed.
A generic section header.
Record of a vaccine administration procedure.
The name or type of immunisation given, often the name of the target disease e.g. 'Hepatitis B'.
An additional comment about the vaccination process.
A generic section header.

An issue or obstacle which adversely impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual. The definition of a problem is deliberately kept rather loose and inclusive of a formal biomedical diagnosis so as to capture any real or perceived concerns that may adversely affect an individual's wellbeing to any degree.
Identification of the index problem, issue or diagnosis.
A narrative description of the  issue, problem or diagnosis.
The assessed overall severity of the index problem.

annotations.comment: Coding of the severity with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date / time when the problem was first identified by the individual.
Additional status and contextual qualifiers factors related to a problem/diagnosis.
Description of the impact of the problem or diagnosis on the patient as a whole. Unlike 'severity' this can be used to compare the clinical impact of different problems.
The problem has had no impact on the subject.
The problem has had very little overall impact on the subject's life or health.
The problem has had considerable overall impact on the subject's life or health.
The problem has threatened the subject's life.
The problem was fatal to the subject.
The degree to which the problem is active and relevant within the current clinical context.
The problem or diagnosis is currently active and clinically relevant.
The problem or diagnosis is not completely resolved but is inactive or felt less relevant to the current clinical context.
The problem or diagnosis is completely resolved and therefore not relevant to the current clinical context.
The problem or issue is of a recurring nature but is currently quiescent.
A text comment on the active status e.g describing the circumstances or evidence for resolution of a problem.
Temporal context indicator aligned with SNOMEDCT.
An issue occuring in the past.
An issue which ocurred at present.
Episodicity is used within a primary care context to distinguish between ongoing and new episodes of a problem or diagnosis, primarily for public health or quality assessment purposes.
The first ever occurence of this problem or diagnosis.
A new occurence of an existing problem or diagnosis.
Part of an ongoing occurence of an existing problem or diagnosis.

In episodic care contexts (commonly  secondary care) it is common to categorise/ organise problems according to their relationship to the principal problem or diagnosis being addressed during that episode of care. These categories may also be used for clinical coding, reporting and billing purposes.
The main condition treated or investigated during the relevant episode of care.
The main procedure performed during the relevant episode of care.
A co-morbidity is a condition that exists at the start of the episode of care, which requires treatment, diagnostic procedures or increased clinical care/monitoring.
A complication is a condition not present at the start of the episode of care which arises during the episode of care, or is a result of a procedure or treatment during that episode.
Any other problem or issue deemed significant to the patient's care which does not fall into the one of other categories.
Positive statement/s about problems or diagnoses that need to be recorded as clinically excluded from the health record at a specific point in time.
A statement about exclusion of use of known problems or diagnoses in the health record.

annotations.comment: For example: "No known significant problems or diagnoses"; or "No evidence of" or "Never diagnosed with" (diabetes).

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the Exclusion not captured in other fields.
The date at which the exclusion was last clinically asserted, affirmed or confirmed.
A generic section header.
A clinical activity that has been carried out for therapeutic or diagnostic purposes.
The name of the procedure.
Comments about the procedure.
Positive statement/s about procedures that need to be recorded as clinically excluded from the health record at a specific point in time.
A statement about exclusion of procedures performed in the health record.

annotations.comment: For example: "No known operations or significant procedures" or "No previous" (appendicectomy).

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the Exclusion not captured in other fields.
The date at which the exclusion was last clinically asserted, affirmed or confirmed.
A generic section header.
Section structure which mimics the openHR medication (authorisation) event record.
Record of the order or recommendation of a single medication item.
Medication order details.
Records details of a medication product, dosage and administration directions, for use within medication recommendation, order, administration and dispensation records.
Mandatory medication name coded using a SNOMED CT/dm+d term where possible, allowing plain text for historical/patient reported items , extemporaneous preparations or those not registered in dm+d.

annotations.comment: e.g.â€œCitalopram tab 20mgâ€, "Trimethoprim"

localizedDescriptions.en: A single plain text phrase describing the entire medication dosage and administration directions, including dose quantity and medication frequency.

annotations.comment:
e.g. â€œI tablet at nightâ€ or â€œ20mg at 10pmâ€
This is the form of dosage direction text normally available from UK GP systems.

localizedDescriptions.en: A parsable 'dose syntax' which carries dose strength, dose timing, dose duration and maximum dose information.

annotations.comment:
e.g. "20-30mg ^4/6h prn [180mg /24h]" = 20 to 30 mgs, up to 4-6 hourly as required. Maximum 180mg in 24 hours. The 'as required reason' e.g 'for pain' should be carried in the Additional Instruction element. Note that this is generally a symptom and is not the same as the Indication which will usually describe a diagnosis or condition.
Where supported, this would generally be used to exchange  dosage information between systems, while Structured dose directions are likely to be used only within openEHR-based systems.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional multiple dosage or administration instructions as plain text. This may include guidance to the prescriber, patient or person administering the medication.

annotations.comment: e.g. â€œOmit morning dose on day of procedureâ€, "for pain or fever"

localizedDescriptions.en: Multiple plain text instructions intended for patient or carer. This is carried as a specific element in addition to 'Additional instructions' to align with legacy GP system behaviour.

annotations.comment: Intended for general advice for the medication course as a whole, as might be carried in a Patient Information Leaflet (PIL) and not for specific dosage instructions. In practice the use of this element is likely to overlap with information recorded in the 'Additional instruction' element.

localizedDescriptions.en: Multiple plain text to record complex dispensing arrangements, particularly for Controlled Drug instalment dispensing.  This is carried as a specific element in addition to 'Additional instructions' to align with legacy GP system behaviour.

annotations.comment: e.g. â€œDispense weeklyâ€

localizedDescriptions.en: Details of the overall course of medication.
The status of this prescription in an ambulatory (outpatient/GP/community) context.
This an active medication.
This is a medication that has been issued. dispensed or administered but has now been discontinued.
A medication which was ordered or authorised but has been cancelled prior to being issued, dispensed or adiminstered.
The medication course has been completed.
This medication order has been superseded by another.
The date and/or time that the medication course should begin.
The date and/or time that the medication course should finish.
The clinical indication or reason for ordering the medication. Coded terms are preferable.

annotations.comment: e.g. "Angina". The Indication generally describes a condition or diagnosis .

localizedDescriptions.en: A link to the record which contains the Indication for this medication order.
Additional comment or recommendation about the medication course e.g. 'Patient named supply', 'unlicensed medication', 'Foreign brand' or monitoring recommendations.
Summary of key medication events and dates, normally carried within a Medication Statement Entry.
Summary of a medication event. Often this will be simply one or more key dates but further event detail may be required in some circumstances.
The date at which the medication prescription was last issued. This refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication.
Summary of a medication event. Often this will be simply one or more key dates but further event detail may be required in some circumstances.
The date at which the medication was first issued. 'Issued' refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication.
Summary of a medication event. Often this will be simply one or more key dates but further event detail may be required in some circumstances.
The date at which the medication order was last reviewed.
Summary of a medication event. Often this will be simply one or more key dates but further event detail may be required in some circumstances.
The date at which the medication was discontinued.
Records an event in the â€˜supplyâ€™ of the medication to the patient, â€˜supplyâ€™ covering repeat authorisation, prescription issue, administration and dispensing of the medication.
Details relevant to discontinuation of the medication.
The reason why a medication was discontinued.
A link to the original record of the medication event.
Record a single medication event.
Records details of a medication product, dosage and administration directions, for use within medication recommendation, order, administration and dispensation records.
Mandatory medication name coded using a SNOMED CT/dm+d term where possible, allowing plain text for historical/patient reported items , extemporaneous preparations or those not registered in dm+d.

annotations.comment: e.g.â€œCitalopram tab 20mgâ€, "Trimethoprim"

localizedDescriptions.en: A single plain text phrase describing the entire medication dosage and administration directions, including dose quantity and medication frequency.

annotations.comment:
e.g. â€œI tablet at nightâ€ or â€œ20mg at 10pmâ€
This is the form of dosage direction text normally available from UK GP systems.

localizedDescriptions.en: A plain text description of medication single dose amount, as described in the AoMRC medication headings.

annotations.comment:
e.g. "30 mg" or "2 tabs".
UK Secondary care clinicians and systems normally minimally structure their dose directions, separating Dose amount and Dose timing (often referred to as Dose and Frequency). This format is not normally used in GP systems.

localizedDescriptions.en: A plain text description of medication dose frequency,  as described in the AoMRC medication headings.

annotations.comment:
e.g. "Twice a day", "At 8am 2pm and 10pm".
UK Secondary care clinicians and systems normally minimally structure their dose directions, separating Dose amount and Dose timing (often referred to as Dose and Frequency). This format is not normally used in GP systems.

localizedDescriptions.en: A parsable 'dose syntax' which carries dose strength, dose timing, dose duration and maximum dose information.

annotations.comment:
e.g. "20-30mg ^4/6h prn [180mg /24h]" = 20 to 30 mgs, up to 4-6 hourly as required. Maximum 180mg in 24 hours. The 'as required reason' e.g 'for pain' should be carried in the Additional Instruction element. Note that this is generally a symptom and is not the same as the Indication which will usually describe a diagnosis or condition.
Where supported, this would generally be used to exchange  dosage information between systems, while Structured dose directions are likely to be used only within openEHR-based systems.

localizedDescriptions.en: A structural representation of the elements carried by the dose syntax in 'Parsable dose strength/timing' i.e. dose strength, dose timing, dose duration and maximum dose.

annotations.comment: Structured dose directions will normally be used within openEHR systems rather than in cross-system communication but may be helpful where legacy systems expose some structured data e.g Direction duration

localizedDescriptions.en: The duration of a single dose direction. Where multiple dose directions are required for a course of medication e.g for a tapering or increasing dose, the duration refers to the duration of a single direction, not the whole course.

annotations.comment:
e.g. "for 7 days", "Continue indefinitely".
"Continue indefinitely", and "Do not discontinue" are normally applied to medication discharge orders and recommendations.

localizedDescriptions.en: The duration of a single dose direction. Where multiple dose directions are required for a course of medication e.g for a tapering or increasing dose, the duration refers to the duration of a single direction, not the whole course.
The medication should be continued indefinitely.
The medication should be continued indefinitely and the prescriber highly recommends that it should never be discontinued. This is an AoMRC Clinical Headings recommendation.

The duration of a single dose direction. Where multiple dose directions are required for a course of medication e.g for a tapering or increasing dose, the duration refers to the duration of a single direction, not the whole course.
Additional multiple dosage or administration instructions as plain text. This may include guidance to the prescriber, patient or person administering the medication.

annotations.comment: e.g. â€œOmit morning dose on day of procedureâ€, "for pain or fever"

localizedDescriptions.en: Details of the overall course of medication.
The status of this prescription in an ambulatory (outpatient/GP/community) context.
This an active medication.
This is a medication that has been issued. dispensed or administered but has now been discontinued.
A medication which was ordered or authorised but has been cancelled prior to being issued, dispensed or adiminstered.
The medication course has been completed.
This medication order has been superseded by another.
The date and/or time that the medication course should begin.
The date and/or time that the medication course should finish.
The clinical indication or reason for ordering the medication. Coded terms are preferable.

annotations.comment: e.g. "Angina". The Indication generally describes a condition or diagnosis .

localizedDescriptions.en: A link to the record which contains the Indication for this medication order.
Additional comment or recommendation about the medication course e.g. 'Patient named supply', 'unlicensed medication', 'Foreign brand' or monitoring recommendations.
Records an event in the â€˜supplyâ€™ of the medication to the patient, â€˜supplyâ€™ covering repeat authorisation, prescription issue, administration and dispensing of the medication.
Details related to the authorisation or issue of the medication.
The type of prescription authorised or issued.
GP repeat prescribing service.
Repeat issues are managed by the dispenser.
A single issue prescription.
A coded value describing the kind of 'contract' in place under which the medication was supplied. Multiple endorsements / contracts are allowed.

annotations.comment:
e.g."ACBS" or â€œPrivateâ€
Assume "Standard" as default

localizedDescriptions.en: Contraceptive endorsed product.
SLS endorsed product included in Part XVIIIB of the Drug Tariff.
ACBS endorsed product  included in Part XV (Borderline Substances) of the Drug Tariff. May not be prescribed privately.
Assorted flavours endorsed product.
The medication was supplied privately.
The medication can only be supplied by a hospital.
Product pack is included in Part XVIIIA of the Drug Tariff  i.e. Schedule 1.
The contract or scheme which applies to this medication.
The prescription was issued solely on a paper prescription.
The medication was marked as issued without a printed prescription or electronic token being created.
The prescription was issued on a handwritten prescription.
The prescription was issued elctronically.
The prescription was dispensed.
The prescription was issued via a repeat dispensing arrangement.
The patient  is self--prescribing i.e. Over-the-counter prescribing.
NHS Scotland Minor Ailments Service (MAS).
NHS SCotland Acute Medication Service (AMS).
NHS Scotland Chronic Medication Service (CMS).
NHS Scotland Unscheduled Care (CPUS).
NHS England  Electronic Prescription Service 1 (EPS1).
NHS England  Electronic Prescription Service 2 (EPS2).
The agency responsible for authorising or issuing the medication.
The medication was issued or authorised by the general practice.
The medication was authorised or issued outside the patient's registered general practice. The exact agency is unknown.
A hospital department is responsible for the medication.
A health carer in another practice is responsible for the medication.
The prescription was issued or authorised by an Out of Hours service.
Details of the product supplied.
Medication quantity expressed using SNOMEDCT units of measure.
A narrative description of the medication quantity.
The expiration date of the medication administered. this may be a whole or partial date.

annotations.comment: e.g. May 2013

localizedDescriptions.en: The batch number, in plain text, of the medication administered.
Details of authorisation of a medication.
The number of repeat issues authorised. A figure of zero implies that this is a single 'acute' prescription.

annotations.comment:
Example: 12
Source: GP systems

localizedDescriptions.en: The minimum period advised between issues.

annotations.comment:
Example: 28 days
Source: GP systems

localizedDescriptions.en: The maximum period advised between issues.

annotations.comment:
Example: 56 days
Source: GP systems

localizedDescriptions.en: Details of a single issue of an acute or repeat medication prescription.
The number of repeats issued since the last authorisation.
The number of days for which this issue was supplied.
Any additional comments regarding thos medication event.
Record a single medication event.
Records details of a medication product, dosage and administration directions, for use within medication recommendation, order, administration and dispensation records.
Mandatory medication name coded using a SNOMED CT/dm+d term where possible, allowing plain text for historical/patient reported items , extemporaneous preparations or those not registered in dm+d.

The medication should be continued indefinitely and the prescriber highly recommends that it should never be discontinued. This is an AoMRC Clinical Headings recommendation.

The duration of a single dose direction. Where multiple dose directions are required for a course of medication e.g for a tapering or increasing dose, the duration refers to the duration of a single direction, not the whole course.
Additional multiple dosage or administration instructions as plain text. This may include guidance to the prescriber, patient or person administering the medication.

annotations.comment: e.g. â€œOmit morning dose on day of procedureâ€, "for pain or fever"

localizedDescriptions.en: Details of the overall course of medication.
The status of this prescription in an ambulatory (outpatient/GP/community) context.
This an active medication.
This is a medication that has been issued. dispensed or administered but has now been discontinued.
A medication which was ordered or authorised but has been cancelled prior to being issued, dispensed or adiminstered.
The medication course has been completed.
This medication order has been superseded by another.
The date and/or time that the medication course should begin.
The date and/or time that the medication course should finish.
The clinical indication or reason for ordering the medication. Coded terms are preferable.

annotations.comment: e.g. "Angina". The Indication generally describes a condition or diagnosis .

localizedDescriptions.en: A link to the record which contains the Indication for this medication order.
Additional comment or recommendation about the medication course e.g. 'Patient named supply', 'unlicensed medication', 'Foreign brand' or monitoring recommendations.
Records an event in the â€˜supplyâ€™ of the medication to the patient, â€˜supplyâ€™ covering repeat authorisation, prescription issue, administration and dispensing of the medication.
Details related to the authorisation or issue of the medication.
The type of prescription authorised or issued.
GP repeat prescribing service.
Repeat issues are managed by the dispenser.
A single issue prescription.
A coded value describing the kind of 'contract' in place under which the medication was supplied. Multiple endorsements / contracts are allowed.

annotations.comment:
e.g."ACBS" or â€œPrivateâ€
Assume "Standard" as default

localizedDescriptions.en: Contraceptive endorsed product.
SLS endorsed product included in Part XVIIIB of the Drug Tariff.
ACBS endorsed product  included in Part XV (Borderline Substances) of the Drug Tariff. May not be prescribed privately.
Assorted flavours endorsed product.
The medication was supplied privately.
The medication can only be supplied by a hospital.
Product pack is included in Part XVIIIA of the Drug Tariff  i.e. Schedule 1.
The contract or scheme which applies to this medication.
The prescription was issued solely on a paper prescription.
The medication was marked as issued without a printed prescription or electronic token being created.
The prescription was issued on a handwritten prescription.
The prescription was issued elctronically.
The prescription was dispensed.
The prescription was issued via a repeat dispensing arrangement.
The patient  is self--prescribing i.e. Over-the-counter prescribing.
NHS Scotland Minor Ailments Service (MAS).
NHS SCotland Acute Medication Service (AMS).
NHS Scotland Chronic Medication Service (CMS).
NHS Scotland Unscheduled Care (CPUS).
NHS England  Electronic Prescription Service 1 (EPS1).
NHS England  Electronic Prescription Service 2 (EPS2).
The agency responsible for authorising or issuing the medication.
The medication was issued or authorised by the general practice.
The medication was authorised or issued outside the patient's registered general practice. The exact agency is unknown.
A hospital department is responsible for the medication.
A health carer in another practice is responsible for the medication.
The prescription was issued or authorised by an Out of Hours service.
Details of the product supplied.
Medication quantity expressed using SNOMEDCT units of measure.
A narrative description of the medication quantity.
The batch number, in plain text, of the medication administered.
Details of a single issue of an acute or repeat medication prescription.
The number of days for which this issue was supplied.
A link or reference to the record where the repeat medication was last authorised.
Any additional comments regarding thos medication event.
